<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 119, 379, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™

CANDIDATE NAME  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 221, 175, 250]]<|/det|>
CENTRE NUMBER

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|>
CANDIDATE NUMBER  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[735, 212, 905, 256]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 276, 905, 292]]<|/det|>
0625/32  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 265, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 3 Theory (Core)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 300, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
February/March 2022  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 325, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 383, 359, 399]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 574]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(10 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 603, 220, 618]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 619, 728, 651]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Fig. 1.1 shows some masses on a mass hanger attached to an elastic band. The elastic band is stretched by the masses.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 109, 720, 395]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 408, 532, 426]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 440, 144, 459]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 440, 653, 459]]<|/det|>
The total mass of the masses and the mass hanger is \(300\mathrm{g}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 470, 670, 489]]<|/det|>
Calculate the total weight of the masses and the mass hanger.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 578, 920, 597]]<|/det|>
<form>total weight = .................................................... N [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
A student pulls the mass hanger down and then releases it. The mass hanger and masses oscillate up and down.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 920, 151]]<|/det|>
The student uses a stop-watch to time 20 oscillations. Fig. 1.2 shows the time reading on the stop-watch after the \(20^{\text{th}}\) oscillation.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[391, 160, 601, 312]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 327, 534, 346]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 359, 181, 378]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 359, 868, 377]]<|/det|>
Determine the time in seconds for 20 oscillations from the time shown in Fig. 1.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[379, 420, 920, 439]]<|/det|>
<form>time for 20 oscillations = .................................................... s [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 452, 181, 470]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 452, 598, 470]]<|/det|>
Calculate the time in seconds for **one** oscillation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[379, 545, 920, 562]]<|/det|>
<form>time for one oscillation = .................................................... s [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 577, 144, 594]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 577, 920, 610]]<|/det|>
When the student pulls the mass hanger down, energy is stored in the elastic band as elastic potential energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 623, 920, 655]]<|/det|>
Describe what happens to this energy store when the student releases the mass hanger and it moves upwards.

<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 396, 888, 415]]<|/det|>
The student wants to determine the resistance of the light-dependent resistor (LDR).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 427, 920, 462]]<|/det|>
Draw on Fig. 10.1 to show how the student connects a voltmeter into the circuit. Use the correct symbol for the voltmeter. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 475, 181, 494]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 475, 920, 509]]<|/det|>
The current in the LDR is 0.020A when the potential difference (voltage) across the LDR is 5.4 V.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 521, 494, 539]]<|/det|>
Calculate the resistance of the LDR.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[416, 676, 920, 695]]<|/det|>
<form>resistance of LDR = ............................................... $\Omega$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 707, 146, 725]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 707, 920, 740]]<|/det|>
When the student shines a light onto the LDR, its resistance is \(150\Omega\). The resistance of the variable resistor in the circuit is \(180\Omega\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 753, 752, 772]]<|/det|>
Determine the combined resistance of the LDR and the variable resistor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[393, 814, 920, 832]]<|/det|>
<form>combined resistance = .................................................. $\Omega$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 845, 920, 863]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 636, 91]]<|/det|>
A battery charger for a laptop computer includes a transformer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 103, 146, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 574, 121]]<|/det|>
The primary voltage \(V_{\mathrm{p}}\) to the transformer is 240 V.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 920, 167]]<|/det|>
The number of turns on the primary coil \(N_{\mathrm{p}}\) is 590 turns and the number of turns on the secondary coil \(N_{\mathrm{s}}\) of the transformer is 48 turns.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 603, 199]]<|/det|>
Calculate the secondary voltage \(V_{\mathrm{s}}\) of the transformer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 365, 920, 384]]<|/det|>
<form>secondary voltage $V_{\mathrm{s}} =$ ............................................... V

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[918, 365, 920, 384]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 395, 767, 415]]<|/det|>
The plug connecting the transformer to the supply voltage contains a fuse.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 427, 386, 445]]<|/det|>
Describe how a fuse works.
